p.note: Pennant's extra-illustrated Tour in Wales, SEVEN, p. 218, includes a watercolour drawing of an unnamed fish, on a page entitled 'Hanmer'. The text at this point appears to be rather confused. See A tour in Wales. MDCCLXX (1778), II, [=A Journey to Snowdon], pp. 188–9, which requires the substitution of pp. 217–18 in vol. I with 'a leaf at the close of this'.

div.p:
I am inexpressibly obliged to you for your last favor & for the pains you are at to gratify my amusement. I take on me your debt to Moses, so please to send me the other half of the note you shall be credited by him for the ballance. Be so good to keep by you what you have collected, till you get the heads from the
octvo
octavo Rapin : I shall then take the liberty of desiring my engraver to add a small matter to the par
cel & then request that it may be sent by the coach. Inclosed is a list of desiderata from Mr Grose. I beg my thanks & best
Complimts
Compliments to him. I wish he could be quickened so that his present may join your prints. I insist on your informing me of the charges you are at on my account.

The cancels & additions I sent, suit the last edition of my
voy. voyage to the Hebrides . The 'last edition' of the 'voy. to the Hebrides' for Pennant writing in 1783, may have been either the 2nd edn. of Part I, A tour in Scotland, and voyage to the Hebrides; MDCCLXXII. Part I. (London: printed for Benj. White, MDCCLXXVI. [1776].), or the first edition of Part II, A tour in Scotland. MDCCLXXII. Part II. (London: printed for Benj. White, 1776). You should change yr
your copy: for perhaps a few more similar may appear but for the elect only. I have been before at some expenses in these donative additions: Mr Chiswel is at these but I ask none but rich friends & such who will not think me obliged to them.

Inclosed is yr
your pig of lead. See A tour in Wales MDCCLXX (London: Henry Hughes, 1778), I, pp. 55–7, for a discussion of 'Roman Pigs of Lead'. the inscription is quite unintelligible, owing to the original false copying.

closer.salute:
but let me with great truth conclude with saying how much I am
Dear Sir
Yr
Your obliged &
affect affectionate humble Servt
Servant

postscript.p:
our Representative is absent. I hope Sir H. Cl. Henry Clinton
will excuse my impertinence in Enclosing to him. I do it as to your friend
Just now my son writes me word that he shall pass thro London in his way to Wales. He shall wait on you about the 18th & call for the pacquet
